Even better, is that if you get bored of the stock content, there is a wealth of content created by the community. New maps, character models/skins, weapons, even total conversion mods that turn this into a completely new game.

What really dissapoints me about the Steam release is that there is no Linux support, even though id Software provided that support years ago, when the game was released. If you run Linux, like myself, go to:

In short, great game; you are missing out if you never played this.

When I played Quake for the first time I can't really say that I fell in love with it at first sight. I guess it's because I was expecting something more "realistic" like Wolfenstein (yeah, I know, at least for the most part of it). Either way, that was because so far I never had the experience of playing anything online. Back in the day I had this friend who eventually convinced me to give it a try. After I started, it didn't take long for me to get hooked on it. Time passed by and someday Quake II was released. Then again, when I tried for the first time I felt kinda disappointed with the game and can't deny that I still feel somehow like that after all those years (I guess it's because I missed that "medieval environment" touch from the first one). Anyway, when I first heard of Quake III, I didn't quite know what I should expect. I just read about the premise that the game was developed to be focused on the multiplayer experience. The irony was that although this title had exactly that concept in mind, that was the only one that I never had the chance to play with other people. Hmm what is there to say? For me it felt like a polished version of Quake II's multiplayer and later it wasn't hard to compare it with Unreal Tournament (which I won't deny that I liked better). Besides that, back then there were some really interesting mods involving the game's engine, like for example "Bid for Power", which had some DBZ characters and levels to play on. Overall, it's not a bad game, you can even play it casually if you're not in the mood to go through a whole set of matches.

Interesting good game, for which you can kill a lot of hours. You can compete with bots, but you can get online, which is much harder and has already developed strong community of gamers. THE game that got me into First Person Shooters (FPSes)!
My Steam review is based on the old CD ROM version and Sega Dreamcast version of Quake III Arena, so my Steam stats don't reflect my actual playtime with it.

PROS:
+Wicked frenetic gameplay -breakneck speed.
+LOW hardware requirements: Q3A is netbook friendly.
+HUGE online community with countless online matches to jump into all the time.
+Pretty good single player campaign and bot matches, when you can't get online.
+Tons of user-created maps, mods, and arenas can be found online...for free. 
+User-created content is also compatible with free, legal, open-source Q3 clones (OpenArena, Nexuiz Classic).
+Runs on Linux and Mac natively, thanks to ioQuake3. 

CONS:
-"Old" graphics, given you're a graphics snob.
-ATI GPUs have issues with GL drivers, but can be fixed via "testapp" and turning off the GL Extension.

Fucking. Hell. Yes. The Arena is a cruel, cruel Mistress - she will build you up, only to break you, & just when you think you're rid of her, she'll drag you back into her clutches.

In short, for those of you who are woefully unaware, Quake 3 is hands down the pinnacle of the "Old School" '90s FPSs designed by the original id Software team, using an entirely different Gameplay model than the Modern FPSs of CoD & BF. A more common term for it is "Twitch Gaming" due to the extreme level of reaction time required to truly match up against not only other players, but also the Bots. To quote Dark Souls - "Prepare to Die", because you will, over, & over, & over.

Seriously, buy it. Once you do, get ioQuake 3 (Google it), & the Quake 3 Widescreen Fixer Mod.

As far as the Online Multiplayer portion (which is arguably 95% of the Game) fear not, for the MP Community is still extremely active, & if you're of the ultra-competitive nature, the CPMA Mod (Challenge Pro Mode Arena - the Standard in Q3 Competitive Play since nearly the very beginning) ups the ante by making an already difficult Game even harder (works both Online (PvP) & Offline (Bots).

See you in the Arena, challenger.... If you dare ;D

P.S. You're also going to want to check out "Defrag" at some point or another, if for nothing else then to just learn more about THE most insane Mod of all time, hands down.

[h1]An Awesome and Highly Addictive Arena FPS That will Test & Develop Your FPS Skills![/h1]

Quake III Arena is an awesome fast-paced arena-styled multiplayer FPS game. A pure deathmatch game at it's best. The controls are perfect, the vanilla graphics are still good today, and the gameplay... fucking awesome! One of my favorite features is the ability to play against bots with friends. Very fun if you just want to co-op in the game.

I will say one thing. This game will test your skills and even help you improve your aim and reaction time as the combat is fast and fierce. After playing this game, I can say I am better at FPS games, especially ones with rocket launchers ;). This is one thing I cannot say you will get from most FPS games. This gives it another reason why this game kicks so much a$$! Not only are you having fun, but you are excersising your hand-to-eye coordination.

[h1]Easy To Mod[/h1]

This game is also very easy to mod. All you need to do is open the .pk3 files in a program like WinZip or WinRar and you can replace the game's sound effects, graphics, and models with custom ones you either downloaded or made yourself.

Talking about mods, I highly recommend downloading ioQuake3 ( http://ioquake3.org ). It replaces Quake 3's rendering engine to suit modern machines giving you better net code and the ability to match your computer's native resolution. You can also download other mods for ioQuake3 to improve the game. Some other mods I recommend is the high res texture pack ( http://ioquake3.org/extras/replacement_content ) and the Metal-Tech v2.0 mod that replaces the textures for the weapons with higher res ones ( http://www.moddb.com/mods/metal-tech-v20-revolutions ).

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

On final note, this game is pure awesomeness and has a high replay value. If you are interested in playing a fast-paced FPS game to test out or improve upon your twitch skills, this is the game for you!

Quake III Arena was the first FPS game that I ever played in my childhood. You know what they say: respect your freaking elders.

[h1]Mind Numbing Fun[/h1]
The third game in the Quake series and I find myself oddly conflicted.

On one hand I absolutely love the concept of these arena shooters based on id Software I.P. On the other, I think Unreal Tournament did a heck of a lot better than Quake 3 in many respects.

The game is fairly straightforward, fix the issues for modern computer (or use source ports) go to the options, pick your player model (I favor DOOM), set your name and have at it. The main arena mode is fairly enjoyable, the bots can be quite challenging on all difficulties save for one (I'll let you figure out which one) and while I'm not too fond of the maps themselves, they can be a blast to run around on.

I love any game with a skirmish or instant action mode. Set the bots you want, pick a map and go. It's good stuff.

Now, in terms of map design, variety, presentation and the way the bots interact with the player and taunt each other, I think Unreal Tournament is better by leaps and bounds. While I'm sure Quake 3's map design is catered toward rocket jumps and frantic shooter action, I quite prefer the variety in maps and aesthetics UT offered over the red skies and full textures of the Arena Eternal.

Quake 3's menus are dull and boring. Just red text, a sniper's cross hair and flaming words that scream Quake III Arena on a black backdrop. The menu's feel so rushed and unfinished it's honestly disappointing, it has no identity, it's like a fan game. I honestly think UT wins in terms of presentation to be honest.

Bot dialogue goes away so fast and there's no way (that I can find) to view past chat messages in game which sucks. Bot interaction with the player is such a cool concept.

I haven't tried the multiplayer, mostly because Oceania has such cruddy ping and I don't want to have to deal with players who are so good at the game that their ego makes up their entire gaming personality.

Now, as far as recommending the game goes: [b]YES![/b] I honestly would recommend this game over Quake Live just because of the bots and how much more simplistic it is. If you can troubleshoot some of the known issues players encounter (I never did) you'll have a blast. There's still a multiplayer community so if that tickles your fancy you might enjoy Quake III Arena.

[b]NOTE:[/b] A consistent issue I've found with Q3A is that when launched the game will run but no window show's up and the game will continue to count hours. No other games can be played nor steam shut down forcing me to restart my computer. I found out that this can be remedied by opening the task manager, finding the Quake 3 exe process under processes and ending it. Relaunch the game and BAM, good to go.

However, this is not a full proof solution and sometimes Steam doesn't realize that the game has been shut down.

Quake 3 is a disappointing entry in id Software's catalogue.  It's one of the first major content-free "games", that is to say, the developers didn't spend any time making content, level design or storytelling for the game, relying instead on the hopes that other players will be an acceptable substitute for content.   They aren't. 

Because the game had no content, once the players moved on to other games, there was nothing left to leave a mark on the landscape for Quake 3, it's a sadly forgettable footnote in an otherwise respectable history. 

People trying to play this for nostalgias sake will be disappointed by both the insane $20 price tag for a game from 1999, and the way it doesn't work properly under Windows 10, requiring a lot of tweaks and hacks just to get to the menu. 

Completely unacceptable stuff and impossible to recommend.    Gamers who want to play video games without any content can try games like Battlefield, CS:GO etc.

The Quake Series -  These games focus on Gameplay and they do it well.  Fun weapons, fast gameplay, rocket jumping, and mosters from knights to demons.  Always focused on speed and Mutiplayer Gaming.

Quake III - in my opinion shares the same space as Counter Strike, Golden Eye, and Unreal Tournament.  This was hands down one of these best mutiplayer combat games ever made.  Tight controls, fun weapons, fun maps, good graphics.  I was so amazed by this game and playing it at a Lan Party one weekend... I dreamed about it in my sleep.  I sometimes wish I could fall in love with another game like this.  If you have freinds and you guys want to try some old school mutiplayer games together... buy copies of this and play against each other... youll love it!!

That being said:  This game and some of the other Quake games really pushed the FPS genre into mainstreme and as a competetive sport.

Nobody is going to confuse this with a modern shooter, but I think Quake III Arean still features some of the most memorable level designs of any FPS and the quick, frantic gameplay remains exceptionally fun even after all these years. I tried some of the Team Areana expansion, but it wasn't anywhere near as good as the main game. Twenty dollars is steep for both, but this often goes on sale and I'll also say the Id Super Pack at just thirty dollars was an awesome buy, even if I have to live with Doom 3 in my library forever.

In my eyes, possibly the greatest skill FPS ever created. Aim, reflex, map knowledge and trickjumping are all important factors in having the upper hand in this game. QuakeLive added a Duel mode which is a 1v1 DM mode. This game has been around for so long and yet still people play even at a competitive level.

If you've never played this game (or quake 1/2), you cant really call yourself an FPS gamer. 

The epitome of twitch skills in a game. The raw skill level of players who still play this game is amazing, and probably the highest average skill level of any FPS community that currently exists. Not only is reaction speed and aim awarded, but equally important is fast and accurate movement (which is a skill in itself, and amazing to watch when you see some of the top level players).

Very high skill ceiling. Brutal for newbies. Rewarding to master. Makes you better at every other FPS. Probably has the highest Signal to Noise ratio of any futuristic FPS.

But if you want to try this now for the first time, play QuakeLive which is an updated version with a more active community.

Quake III Arena is the quintessential Arena shooter. This was the first entry to abandon the single player campaign in favor of a multiplayer only experience. This certainly has its downsides, especially all this time later. Still, Quake III Arena's gameplay is so timeless that there is still a somewhat active community (tournaments are still held). Quake Live's community is far more active though, so that is the game you should probably purchase.

PROS:
- Perfect gameplay that is extremely fast at the highest levels (few modern games are as quick)
- Contains bots and a singleplayer mode so anyone can always find a way to play
- Decent port, but there are better alternatives
- Great game to LAN
- Great performance, can run on practically any modern machine

CONS:
- Community is far less active than Quake Live (finding a match is possible, but often difficult)
- Difficulty for newcomers as most of the playerbase is very experienced
- In the scope of the franchise, the lack of a campaign was an unfortunate precedent

Still better than multiplayer Halo/CoD/MoH/any pathetic MOBA/any boring battle royale/etc. modern garbage.  Classic, fast, fun, accessible, doesn't require a $3000+ overpowered PC arena shooters are still the best if you need multiplayer fun.

[h1] Quake III: Arena [/h1]

[b] An Fun Arena Shooter, But A Bit Too Dated [/b]

[b] Quake III: Arena [/b] was the Quake series' departure from the traditional single-player FPS focus of the era, and instead provided a near-fully focused multiplayer experience (with some singleplayer content). While a compelling game for many multiplayer fans at the time, I was barely a fetus when this title came out and thus "just" missed the mark of playing it myself with my own barely developed hands. Thus, here I am now critiquing a game from my birth year trying my best to combine my understanding of its value to the industry with my delayed experience of playing it myself. This will be fun...

I mostly focused on the singleplayer aspect of this game since there are very few legitimate servers still in existence, and every time I tried to join one of those they would be empty or full of AFK players. Thus, my experience was with the solo arena mode...and it wasn't half bad! Granted the concept of fighting AI opponents in a random stage got a bit repetitive, but each stage was unique and provided a lot of action to get accustomed with the mechanics in this title.

The mechanics are pretty much the same as other Quake games. Here, you will pick up weapons from specific spots around each map as well as ammo from similar spots. There are some upgrades around the map as well that can make your character deal more damage or run faster, and there aren't too many that complicate the game flow or mechanics too much.

Enemies are pretty stupid at the "normal" setting (forgot the name but it was the perceived middle difficulty). They'll be entertaining and run around the map fighting you or each other, and are capable of getting some kills (mostly not on you though). Maps are designed with enough verticality and size to allow for some breathing room between fights, and the textures are about the same as Quake II's.

However, I didn't really get to experience the game's multiplayer, which is what the game was designed around. The singleplayer version of it was alright, but there weren't enough servers in my tie zone to get into games consistently, and honestly playing it this far down the line it would be lacking the original feel anyway. Therefore, I can't review the game based off of that component.

It is still a weird thing to me that ID Software decided to create a multiplayer focused Quake so early on in the IP's lifetime. While it definitely increased the game's popularity in the short-run, in the long-run it stifled the game's potential for solid singleplayer adventures like in the first two titles. I'm aware that Quake IV was somewhat of a return to form, but the lack of future sequels afterwards proved that the original formula lost its audience in ID Software's eyes.

Overall, this is a game that I can [b] Recommend [/b] despite difficulties in actually experiencing its multiplayer components. It has a cheesy, basic, but fun solo arena mode, and the mechanics are solid, yet familiar enough to get some enjoyment out of. Try this one out if you enjoyed the first two and would like an arena style version to mess around in, but don't be surprised if there is a lack of content in that same regard. It's a classic FPS multiplayer shooter that had its day and age, but as far as solo play goes its a bit generic now.

[h2] Final Verdict: 6/10 (Above Average) [/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

Doom, Quake, and Quake II would set the scene, but it was Quake III that had the fluidity, graphical chops, and level design that would refine the FPS arena deathmatch to perfection. As a result, every multiplayer FPS arena shooter that came after owes it's legacy to this game. It defined a number of conventions of the genre that still hold to this day in other similar games.

Unlike iD's previous Quake installments, this game has no singleplayer campaign in the traditional sense. The campaign is rather just a series of arena deathmatches with increasing numbers of bots of varying intelligence over different maps. If you can clear all the matches, you win.

Sadly online multiplayer is mostly dead, but playing single player is still a challenge because the bot intelligence can be set really high. It will test your FPS skills out and make you a better player, guaranteed.

It's a classic in every sense of the word and still holds it's own today. It will even run on potato computers and look great doing so.

It's terribly difficult to put into words how much Quake III means to me, but I'll briefly attempt to do so regardless. If you totaled all of my hours on various ioquake3 mods together with Quake Live, my hours would total in the high hundreds (maybe more). My biological and social experience of growing up as a human being was, and still is haunted by memories of Quake III. When I skip to the bus stop in the early morning, I cavort to my destination in imitation of Bitterman's [i] bunnyhop[/i]. When I defend myself from the beasts of my nightmares, I do so with the [i] Lightning Gun[/i]. Quake III was the second womb I lived in, and when I expire I ought to be buried with a copy of her cradled in my arms. What for most people is a game like any other is my providence, my truest and most uncompromising love. I need her like a flower needs sunlight

**Quake III Arena – The Pinnacle of Fast-Paced Arena Combat**

Quake III Arena is a monumental title that redefined the landscape of multiplayer first-person shooters upon its release in 1999. Nearly a quarter of a century later, it remains a shining example of skill-based gameplay, lightning-fast action, and a vibrant community that has stood the test of time.

From the moment you enter the game, you’re greeted with stunning visuals that, while reflective of their era, still exude a timeless quality. The iconic map designs, with their intricate layouts and unique aesthetics, create a dynamic environment that promotes skillful movement and strategic play. Each arena is meticulously crafted, offering varied gameplay experiences that challenge players to master both the environment and their opponents.

The gameplay in Quake III Arena is nothing short of exhilarating. The speed at which players move, combined with precise controls, creates an adrenaline-fueled experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The weapon variety is fantastic, with classics like the Rocket Launcher and Railgun offering distinct playstyles. Mastering the nuances of each weapon is essential for success, and the learning curve is both rewarding and addictive.

One of the most significant strengths of Quake III Arena is its emphasis on skill. Every match is a test of reflexes, strategy, and precision. The absence of complex loadouts or perks ensures that players rely solely on their abilities, making each victory feel hard-earned and satisfying. This pure form of competitive gameplay has fostered a passionate community that continues to thrive, with tournaments and events that showcase top-tier talent.

The game’s online multiplayer mode was groundbreaking at its release and remains a highlight. The ability to face off against players from around the world in fast-paced matches adds endless replayability. The matchmaking system, although simple, facilitates thrilling encounters that are both intense and rewarding.

Quake III Arena also offers a robust single-player experience with its bot matches, allowing players to hone their skills and experiment with different tactics. The AI provides a satisfying challenge, making it a great way to practice without the pressure of online competition.

The modding community surrounding Quake III is another testament to its enduring legacy. User-created content, from new maps to total conversions, continues to enrich the game and keep it fresh. This community-driven approach has ensured that there is always something new to discover, whether you’re a newcomer or a returning player.

In summary, Quake III Arena is an iconic title that encapsulates the essence of competitive arena shooters. Its fast-paced gameplay, skill-based mechanics, and rich community make it a timeless classic that deserves recognition. Whether you’re reliving the glory days or discovering it for the first time, Quake III Arena offers an exhilarating experience that remains unmatched in the world of gaming. Jump in, embrace the chaos, and experience the thrill of the arena!

[h3]Welcome to the Arena.[/h3]

Dennis Fong won John Carmack's Ferrari 328 as part of a Quake 1 MP championship in 1997, ID knew how fun it was to run around in Doom MP, they made Quake more fast and more vertical, when developing Q3A they decided to focus fully on MP and as a result, arguably created the competitive FPS genre or at the very least propelled it, trailblazing with the id tech 3 engine, which was used for Call of Duty, Wolfenstein Enemy Territory, and had a lot of code which Valve's goldsrc used - that's right, HL1, CS, and COD owe a lot of their success to the blueprint that ID discovered and crafted.

Carmack has said in later years that Q3A was never designed to be this brutal game that is very difficult to learn, it just worked out that way, just like in Chess if you fail it's really your fault, there isn't anything to get lucky with aside from some great prefires or spam or happening to run into someone, but there's no artificial way to take the lead, you just have to be better than your opponent, and as a result, if you're interested in proving who the best player is, Q3A offers one of the most balanced experiences for a real fair competitive arena.

It's really hard to overstate how profound Q3A was for the time it was released, it took an absolute beast of a PC to run at good FPS - back then almost no one was sitting on 200fps and almost no one was above 75hz or 100hz on a CRT. The atmosphere was moody, the game was dark and intimidating, but at the core of it, as a player, it never feels like the game is against you or punishing you, it is FAIR, brutally so, there is no "escape" button to save you, the character designs are kinda wacky, the bot DM maps and bosses ease you in - starting from Q3DM0 the first map against Crash, a very small hallway with only one or two weapons and two opposing spawn points - this is amazing game design - teaching you everything you need to know to get started before throwing you into a deathmatch with multiple bots.

As a kid I gained my skills in those offline deathmatches, and I went online and got blasted, I sat in awe of the skill that some players seemed to have, instead of being discouraged I wanted to live in the world they did - where they were able to put the game on and dominate. So many iconic memories of playing on maps like The Longest Yard - a map where you have access to a railgun, multiple opponents, and almost zero hiding spots and cover, if you had good aim (most people were using rollerball mice pre 2006!) you'd be able to pick players off while hearing that reassuring "IMPRESSIVE, EXCELLENT" driving the dopamine home, iconic.

ID were a bunch of guys who were having fun making the games they thought were great, they had no business blueprint to achieving annual ROI, they had no formula to follow, they operated in a free creative arena and as a result created one of the most fun and balanced competitive arena shooters of all time, dare I say the best, still, because in my eyes, yes it is dated but which modern title can I say is crafted better, overall?

Thanks for reading!
